Appointment 01876 reappointment of Ron she was member of the Seattle public library board of trustees for a term to April 1ST 2026.

Can you introduce yourself for the record?
Yes, thank you to your chair Juarez, I'm happy to introduce Ron's pedigree and reason for appointment today.
Ron was initially appointed to the library board for Mayor Ed Murray in 2016 and served on the board for 4 1/2 years.
In that time he has served as vice president during the years of 2019 and 2020.
During his tenure on the library board, he has been focused on a number of priorities including elevated social justice and creating and establishing social justice policies.
During this period, the Seattle public library has earned a national recognition for its equity work and was named library of the year in 2020 by Ãšthe Gail library Journal.
Several years prior to joining the board Mr. chew also served on the public library foundation board during the library's for all campaign.
To rebuild and renew every library in our system.

Mr. chew is a third generation Seattleite and has gone to Franklin high school, he recently retired from 10 years as the executive director for the international community health services foundation where he helped raise money to support a network of community clinics serving Asian Pacific American immigrants and refugees and other Underserved populations.
He served as director of the Asian museum from 1991 to 2007 and served for more than 13 years as editor of the International Examiner.
The oldest and largest nonprofit communication in the Northwest.
He documents local community history through oral history multimedia projects.
Mr. chew's book was published in 2020 and documents a personalized history of the Asian community in Seattle.
Mr. chew amendments to the community make them a solid addition to the Seattle public library board of trustees and the board supports his reappointment.
Mr. chew regrets that he could not attend today but did send his best wishes to the committee.

And those supporters, they want the Covenant transferred so that it removes any barriers so that they can access the Red barn counsel.
I've spoken to County, parks and Rec, the parks Department seems very adamant about finding a way to get community on that land.

But, how will it benefit the community that actually started this movement, I want to lift up all the voices that have triggered this, and I hope that a lot of city officials, both County and in parks will identify why this was triggered.

I just wanted to say that I fully support removing this restrictive Covenant that is not allowing for this property to be transferred to such an amazing community effort as Nurturing roots.
And transforming this into red barn ranch.

I echo so much, all of Naima's comments in regard to how we need to have a community approach toward food, stability, food Sustainability and Nurturing roots has proven that they have a direct model and direct connection to community organizations and groups to help bring a multitude of services and resources to this base.

So I fully support Uplifting this restrictive Covenant that Unfortunately means there is some type of layers of bureaucracy that Nurturing roots would have to go through in order for them to get this property.
I think Seattle as a city has the opportunity to lead with these kinds of direct actions that mean direct community.
And when we talk about it being in your hands, this is one action you can take as a collective counsel to say you know what, we understand the need for this in the community and we oblige that need.

It is the best way to activate an inactive space.
I am in full support of removing the restrictive Covenant.

But I support and approve this work.
I think it is the right way for the Council to go.
And I would hope that future bureaucracy related to the transfer of this land, Nurturing roots and black farmers collective it be expedited, thank you.

So we are now going to move forward and hear a presentation by the Seattle parks and read recreation on the legislation and I'd like to invite our Presenters and I ask everyone to introduce themselves before the record.
Superintendent is here and he has an eight page Powerpoint and is going to walk us through what we are going to do today regarding the Red barn ranch and North Regnier property.
So we are working today to look at removing the recreational Covenant from the Red barn ranch, which is ranch located outside of Auburn, not in the city limits.
It's about 39 acres.
We are also looking at placing a restrictive Covenant on the North Regnier land bank site which in the future will be a new neighborhood park in the South end.
So with that, I will hand us off to the superintendent.
And you can make introductions and go through the Powerpoint.
Thank you chair Juarez, we've got several folks from parks and recreation here so I will let the two folks that will help me out with the first item introduce themselves.
We will introduce the others as we go along.
Selena we will start with you.
Hi everyone, I'm part of the policy team.
Good afternoon, Max Jacob from the Seattle parks and Rec real estate.
I'm looking at the history on this Jesus, it looks like the city but this way back in 1970.
That is correct.
Okay, can folks see the screen?

Okay, well thank you again, as we get started I want to acknowledge and express my appreciation for all the folks who came to testify today and all the folks who have been advocating on behalf of of a new use for this property.
Particularly for Nurturing roots.
And really, appreciate the advocacy that they are sharing in terms of supporting black forming and investing in the community.
Obviously this really helps us and pushes us to explore different possibilities for the site and really about creative uses.
We appreciate that very much.
And as you said, the idea here is obviously procedural to some extent, to clear the way so we can begin with some more creative thinking.
The next steps for this property have not been identified.
But again we do appreciate the ongoing advocacy and collaboration.
Just to give folks a little bit of a geographic awareness, this is a property just under 40 acres.
South east of Seattle near Auburn, about 30 miles southeast of Seattle.

On the map you can see, it should've show you, you can see that White square, there are some structures in the top left and then there is some Forested land and Wetland areas, so it is a Bitty pretty big piece of property.
It is largely an open space.
In terms of some of the historical context, as you said Councilmember, the city did in fact purchase this property in 1970.
And that is part of the reason why we are here.
The way in which the city acquired this property was utilizing funding from the acquisition office.
Whenever we purchase land we accept these grants with the requirement of placing restrictive covenants on the property as being purchased.
Those restrictive covenants require us to keep the landing use for parks and recreation and continue to provide public access.
So this property has been with us for many years and has been using various different ways.
Most recently there has been camps on the property.
And then they vacated back in 2018.
So then we try to identify what we can do with this property.
Some very practical and pragmatic challenges is where the property is and how much work is required.
Then we began the conversations with the conservation office about what we can do with the property.
Conversation started way back in 2018.
In the property has been vacant since then.
Just a quick overview, this restrictive Covenant comes with a funding source.
Therefore, in order for us to do anything different with this property, we would have to remove the Covenant.
And that is what we are asking for approval.
If we don't remove the covenants, the what we can do on this property is very minimal.
Without it we would not be able to do anything.

It is also important to note that in addition to these covenants strict in the use currently, another step as part of this process would be to take a look at initiative 42, which Councilmembers, you should know, but for the public, it is an initiative that requires any property within the parks and recreation to be utilized for parks and recreation usage.
If the property is to be disposed of, there is some very specific requirements in terms of replacement.
So there are lots of reasons why, we will get into it more deeply.
So there are many reasons why proposition 42 does not really work.
We expected to be coming back to you all to address that.
And then be able to move forward to set missions for this.
But more to come on that.
And so part of the process to remove the Covenant was first getting approval from the recreation conservation office.
We started this back in 2018.
In January we were able to get approval from the Rcl board to remove those covenants.
But in order to remove them we have to put them somewhere else.
And that is where the North Regnier land Bakes come into play.
It has to be a piece of property that has not yet been developed and there are very few that qualify for this.
The North Regnier property is really the only one.

We have one other but that has been identified for other covenants so the other reason why this property, the North Rainier site makes sense, it is a site we are ready seeking additional Rcl money for, so there will be covenants on that property.
This is a great opportunity for us to take advantage of that.
So we are going to ask you to release the existing Covenant deed on the Red barn property and move forward with the North Rainier property.
The timing on this is important.
In order to transfer the covenants to a new property, that cannot yet be developed.
The North Rainier is one of our properties that is moving forward.
And they plan to move forward with that development this summer.
So would like to move the covenants over so we don't slow that down.
To back up just a tiny bit, to show folks where the earth Regnier property is, this is sort of like an acquisition we made, and will build a park about 38,000 square feet.
That is an acre, right?
Yes, just under an acre.
Next slide.
And as we stated several times, this is just the first step in order for us to create some flexibility to do something different with the Red barn ranch property.
Once we remove the covenants, we've already begun engaging to help understand what needs to be done with this property for future use.
So we have to have a better sense of what the future use is.

Ultimately, we would plan on designing and implementing this community envisioned process that would identify long term use and work with a consultant to figure out what will happen with the property.
Again we have to figure out what we need to do to move forward.
And I mentioned with initiative 42, there are also further resources that can be invested.
For example if we needed to invest from the park district, for example.
So some legal analysis and legal work still has to happen.
But this is the first step we are asking for today.

And on the last slide, just asking you all to help us transfer this Covenant from red barn ranch to the North Rainier site allows us to have more options and allows us to continue the development for the North Rainier site.
